MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Compensation for Postponed Trips.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Tourism and Transport if Irish airlines are to be required to pay compensation for holiday and business trips postponed by flight delays.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: Airlines are not liable for compensation in respect of flight delays and there are no plans to require them to pay such compensation. The conditions of contract between a passenger and an airline, which are shown on airline tickets and are standard to all airlines, include the following:

Carrier undertakes to use its best efforts to carry the passengers and baggage with reasonable dispatch. Times shown in timetables or elsewhere are not guaranteed and form no part of this contract. Carrier may, without notice, substitute alternate carriers or aircraft, and may alter or omit stopping places shown on the ticket in case of necessity. Schedules are subject to change without notice. Carrier assumes no responsibility for making connections.

As regards delays caused by over-booking of passengers, most airlines operate a scheme to compensate passengers on scheduled flights who cannot be accommodated on a flight for which they have a reservation. Furthermore, the EC Commission is at present formulating proposals for a scheme of compensation in the event of an airline overbooking passengers on scheduled flights. In addition, the EC Council is at present considering a draft Directive on Package Travel which contains measures to give protection to the consumer in the event of non-performance or poor performance of contract by a tour operator, including overbooking.

asked the Minister for Tourism and Transport the subsidies which have been paid by the Government to Aer Lingus over the past 30 years; and the total sum of dividends paid by the company to the Government during the same period.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: No subsidies have been paid to Aer Lingus over the past 30 years. However, as part of a comprehensive financial restructuring package designed to restore the group to profitability, the Government in 1983 approved the provision of cost alleviation payments to Aerlínte Éireann in recognition of their role in meeting national needs through the provision of a transatlantic service. In the period 1983 to 1986 inclusive, cost alleviation payments totalling £13 million were paid to the airline.

Dividends amounting to £3,209,000 have been paid to the Government by Aer Lingus. The company have also announced a dividend of £3.5 million for the financial year ended 31 March 1989. The dividend figures quoted are inclusive of advance corporation tax.
The total share capital in the Aer Lingus group, all of which is held by the Minister for Finance, is £73.61 million, comprising £36.393 million in Aer Lingus and £47.217 million in Aerlínte.

asked the Minister for Tourism and Transport the guarantees he will give that non-Irish airlines will not move into routes recently taken from Aer Lingus and given to Ryanair exclusively, thereby putting in jeopardy the continuing involvement of an Irish airline on such routes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: It would not be open to me to refuse an application by a non-Irish airline to operate a service on any of the three routes in question viz. I have not, however, received any application from a non-Irish airline to operate on any of the routes concerned.

I should say that the object of the Government's policy is not to protect Irish airlines from competition but to enable the two Irish airlines to meet increasing foreign competition from positions of strength and to take maximum advantage of liberalisation in the Community in the run-up to 1992.
